The '''National Library of Wales''' ({{lang-cy|Llyfrgell Genedlaethol Cymru}}), [[Aberystwyth]], is the national [[legal deposit]] library of [[Wales]] and is one of the [[Welsh Government sponsored bodies]]. It is the biggest library in Wales, holding over 6.5 million books and periodicals, and the largest collections of archives, portraits, maps and photographic images in Wales. The Library is also home to the national collection of Welsh manuscripts, the National Screen and Sound Archive of Wales, and the most comprehensive collection of paintings and topographical prints in Wales.<ref name=NLWstrategy /><ref name=NLWcdp /> As the primary [[research library]] and archive in Wales<ref name="Brinley Jones">{{cite book|last1=Brinley Jones|first1=R.|editor1-last=Fishlock|editor1-first=Trevor|title=In this place: the National Library of Wales|date=2007|publisher=National Library of Wales|location=Aberystwyth|isbn=9781862250543|page=6|chapter=Foreword}}</ref> and one of the largest research libraries in the [[United Kingdom]], the National Library is a member of [[Research Libraries UK|Research Libraries UK (RLUK)]]<ref>{{cite web|title=About us|url=http://www.rluk.ac.uk/about-us/|website=Research Libraries UK|accessdate=21 June 2015}}</ref> and the [[Consortium of European Research Libraries]] (CERL).<ref>{{cite web|title=List of members|url=http://www.cerl.org/membership/list_members|website=[[Consortium of European Research Libraries]]|accessdate=21 June 2015}}</ref>
At the very core of the National Library of Wales is the mission to collect and preserve materials related to Wales and Welsh life and those which can be utilised by the people of Wales for study and research.<ref name=Wales_[journal]_1946>{{cite journal|title=The National Library of Wales|journal=Wales|date=1946|issue=24|pages=61–73}}</ref> [[Welsh language|Welsh]] is the Library's main medium of communication but it does, however, aim to deliver all public services in Welsh and English.<ref>[http://www.llgc.org.uk/fileadmin/documents/pdf/Welsh_Lang_Scheme.pdf Welsh Language Scheme: 2006] at NLW Official website. Retrieved 27 April 2013</ref> In January 2015 the Library in partnership with Wikimedia UK appointed a full-time [[Wikipedian in Residence]] with the aim of developing further its resources on an open licence, to a world-wide audience.<ref>[http://www.llgc.org.uk/blog/?p=9102&lang=en National Library of Wales website;] accessed 20 January 2015</ref><ref>[https://blog.wikimedia.org.uk#National Library of Wales with a birthday gift to Wikipedia [[Wikimedia UK]] blog;] accessed 20 January 2015</ref>
== History == [[File:Sir John Williams, Bart, GCVO, MD - Christopher Williams .jpg|thumb|Sir John Williams, one of the principal founders of the National Library]] In 1873, a committee was set up to collect Welsh material and house it at [[Aberystwyth University|University College]], Aberystwyth. In 1905, the government promised money in its budget to establish a National Library and a National Museum of Wales, and the [[Privy Council]] appointed a committee to decide on the location of the two institutions.<ref name=about-nlw >{{cite web| url=http://www.llgc.org.uk/index.php?id=6| title=About NLW|publisher=NLW official website}}</ref> [[David Lloyd George]], who later became Prime Minister, supported the effort to establish the National Library in Aberystwyth,<ref name=Jenkins /> which was selected as the location of the library after a bitter fight with [[Cardiff]], partly because a collection was already available in the College. [[Sir John Williams, 1st Baronet, of the City of London|Sir John Williams]], physician and book collector, had also said he would present his collection (in particular, the [[Peniarth Manuscripts|Peniarth collection of manuscripts]]) to the library if it were established in Aberystwyth. He also eventually gave £20,000 to build and establish the library. Cardiff was eventually selected as the location of the [[National Museum of Wales]]. Funds for both the National Library and the National Museum were contributed by the subscriptions of the working classes, which was unusual in the establishment of such institutions. In a Prefatory Note to ''A List of Subscribers to the Building Fund'' (1924), the first librarian, John Ballinger, estimates that there were almost 110,000 contributors.<ref name=Jenkins /> The Library and Museum were established by [[Royal Charter]] on 19 March 1907.<ref name=about-nlw /><ref name=Fishlock>{{cite book|last1=Fishlock|first1=Trevor|title=In this place: the National Library of Wales|date=2007|publisher=National Library of Wales|location=Aberystwyth|isbn=9781862250543|pages=11, 35, 86, 92–93, 139–141, 188–189, 193–197}}</ref> The Charter stipulated that if the National Library of Wales should be removed from Aberystwyth then the manuscripts donated by Sir John Williams will become the property of the University College.<ref name=Jenkins /><ref name=nlw-sir-john>{{cite web|title=Sir John Williams' Collection|url=https://www.llgc.org.uk/collections/learn-more/printedmaterials/syrjohnwilliamscollection/|publisher=National Library of Wales|accessdate=26 June 2015}}</ref> A new Royal Charter was granted in 2006.
The National Library of Wales was granted the privilege of legal deposit under the 1911 Copyright Act. Initially, however, the Library could only claim material deemed to be of Welsh and Celtic interest without any restrictions on expensive or limited edition publications.<ref name=Walters >{{cite book|last1=Walters|first1=Gwyn|editor1-last=Jones|editor1-first=Philip Henry|editor2-last=Rees|editor2-first=Eiluned|title=A nation and its books : a history of the book in Wales|date=1998|publisher=National Library of Wales|location=Aberystwyth|isbn= 9781862250093|chapter=The National Library of Wales, the art of the book, and Welsh bibliography|pages=387–398}}</ref> In 1987, the last of these restrictions were removed to make the legal deposit entitlement of the National Library of Wales equal to those of the [[Bodleian Library]], [[Cambridge University Library]], [[Trinity College Library]], Dublin and the [[National Library of Scotland]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bell|first1=Hazel K.|title=Legal deposit in Euston Street|journal=Serials|date=1992|volume=5|issue=3|pages=53–57|url=http://serials.uksg.org/articles/10.1629/050353/galley/198/download/|accessdate=23 July 2015|doi=10.1629/050353}}</ref>
The first use of the [[Library of Congress Classification]] by a library in Britain was at the National Library of Wales in 1913.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Attar|first1=Karen|editor1-last=Howsam|editor1-first=Leslie|title=The Cambridge companion to the history of the book|date=2014|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=Cambridge|pages=17–35|chapter=Books in the library}}</ref>
===Buildings=== On 15 July 1911 [[King George V]] and Queen Mary laid the foundation stone of the National Library of Wales.<ref name=Griffiths>{{cite book|last1=Griffiths|first1=Rhidian|title=Y ddinas ar y bryn : Llyfrgell Genedlaethol Cymru trwy luniau = The city on the hill : The National Library of Wales in pictures|date=2007|publisher=Llyfrgell Genedlaethol Cymru / The National Library of Wales|location=Aberystwyth|isbn=9781862250598}}</ref> Designed by architect [[Sidney Greenslade]], who won the competition to design the building in 1909, the building at Grogythan,<ref>Wmffre, Iwan, 'National Library', ''The Place-Names of Cardiganshire'', Vol. III, pp. 980–981 (BRA British Series 379 (III), 2004, ISBN 1-84171-665-0)</ref> off Penglais Hill, was ready for occupation in August 1915 but the task of transferring the collections was not completed until 1 March 1916, [[St. David's Day]].<ref name=Jenkins /> The central block, or ''[[corps de logis]]'', was added by [[Charles Holden]] to a modified version of Greenslade's design. It was completed in 1937 and is a [[Grade II* listed building]].<ref name=Griffiths /> <ref> {{cite web|url=http://www.britishlistedbuildings.co.uk/wa-10417-national-library-of-wales-penglais-road-p#.Voq_r09_cnM|title=National Library of Wales, Penglais Road, Penglais, Aberystwyth Date Listed: 21 July 1961 Cadw Building ID: 10417 |publisher= British Listed Buildings|accessdate= 4 January 2016}} </ref>
The Library is faced with Portland stone on the upper storeys which contrasts with the Cornish granite below it.<ref name=Wales_[journal]_1946 /> Restoration work was necessary in 1969 and 1983 due to the effects of weathering on the Portland stone.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title = The National Library of Wales: A history of the building.|last = Huws|first = Daniel|publisher = The National Library of Wales|year = 1994|isbn = 0907158676|location = Aberystwyth}}</ref> In recent years many changes have been made to the front part of the building.
The large North Reading Room, where printed books are consulted, has "the proportions of a Gothic Cathedral", being 175 feet long, 47 feet wide and 33 feet high. There are galleries at three levels above the floor. The feasibility of installing a mezzanine floor to make better use of the space has been considered on two occasions. The South Reading Room is used for consulting archives, manuscripts, maps and other printed materials. Carved above the entrance is the room's original name the Print and Maps Room. Above it on the second floor of the south wing is the Gregynog Gallery where temporary and permanent exhibitions display the treasures of the Library's collections.<ref name=":0" />
A six-storey bookstack, which was completed in 1931, was built to increase storage space for the rapidly expanding book collection.<ref name=Griffiths /> A second bookstack was officially opened in March 1982.<ref name=Griffiths /> In 1996, the Third Library Building was opened, doubling the storage capacity of the Library.<ref name=Griffiths /> The second phase of the building was built by T. Alun Evans (Aberystwyth) Ltd.
A fire on 26 April 2013 destroyed a section of roofing in an office area of the building.<ref name=bbc-fire>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-mid-wales-22318791 National Library of Wales fire investigation to begin] [[BBC news]], Mid Wales, 27 April 2013]</ref><ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-22312017 Fire at National Library of Wales, Aberystwyth] BBC News 26 April 2013</ref> Restoration was assisted by a government grant of £625,000.<ref name=NLWminsSep2013>[http://www.llgc.org.uk/fileadmin/fileadmin/docs_gwefan/amdanom_ni/llywodraethiant_llgc/Cofnodion_saesneg/bdd_cof_130927S.pdf NLW Board Minutes, 27 September 2013] at official website</ref>
===Wartime sanctuary=== During the [[Second World War]], many of Britain's most valuable artworks and manuscripts were stored in the National Library of Wales, which provided the evacuated treasures with a refuge from enemy bombing raids.<ref name=Jenkins /><ref name=BBC-da_vinci>{{cite web|title=Da Vinci art put in cave in WWII|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/mid/7820055.stm|publisher=BBC|accessdate=25 June 2015}}</ref> The architect Charles Holden was instructed to design a tunnel for this purpose in the outcrop of rock close to the main building, with the [[British Museum]] sharing in the costs that this incurred. The tunnel was heated and ventilated to ensure the preservation of vellum, papyri and paper during its use from 18 July 1940 until 23 May 1945. In addition to an extensive consignment from the British Museum,<ref name=Jenkins /> which weighed over one hundred tons,<ref name="The British Museum">{{cite web|title=Letter relating to evacuation of the British Museum's collections during the Second World War|url=http://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/archives/l/letter_relating_to_evacuation.aspx|publisher=The British Museum|accessdate=25 June 2015}}</ref> the Library received forty-six boxes of manuscript and printed books from [[Corpus Christi College, Cambridge]] and over a thousand pictures, eighty-two boxes of books and twenty members of staff from the [[National Gallery]].<ref name=Jenkins>{{cite book|last1=Jenkins|first1=David|title=A refuge in peace and war : the National Library of Wales to 1952|date=2002|publisher=National Library of Wales|location=Aberystwyth|isbn=1862250340|pages=xi, 60–65, 93, 96, 99–101, 129, 168, 174, 266–269}}</ref> The Library also received irreplaceable items from other prestigious institutions such as the [[Ashmolean Museum]], Oxford, [[Dulwich College]] and [[the Royal Society]].<ref name=Davies1945>{{cite journal|last1=Davies|first1=William Ll.|title=War-time evacuation to the National Library of Wales|journal=Transactions of the Honourable Society of Cymmrodorion [Trafodion Anrhydeddus Gymdeithas y Cymmrodorion]|date=1945|pages=171–178|url=http://cylchgronaucymru.llgc.org.uk/browse/viewpage/llgc-id:1386666/llgc-id:1412891/llgc-id:1413072/getText|accessdate=26 June 2015}}</ref>
A number of distinguished scholars from the British Museum accompanied the collections to Aberystwyth.<ref name=Jenkins /> Their senior member of staff was Deputy Keeper of Printed Books, Victor Scholderer, who responded to a [http://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_image.aspx?image=ps342852.jpg&retpage=16254 letter] from the Director, [[John Forsdyke|Sir John Forsdyke]], by insisting that he and his colleagues would continue to sleep in the Library so that the tunnel could be checked during the night to ensure that the air conditioning was functioning properly.<ref name="The British Museum"/> Scholderer, an expert on [[incunabula]], produced ''A Handlist of Incunabula in the National Library of Wales'' in gratitude to the hospitality that was afforded to them by the Library.<ref name=Jenkins /> Likewise, [[Arthur E. Popham]], Keeper of Prints and Drawings, dedicated ''The Drawings of Leonardo da Vinci'' ″To the Librarian and staff of the National Library of Wales″.<ref name=Jenkins /><ref name=Davies1945 /> Several other institutions donated funds to the Library as an expression of their gratitude<ref name=Davies1945 /> and Mrs. David Sassoon, London presented two works by Cicero that were printed at Venice in the fifteenth century.<ref name=Dept._of_printed_books_(NLW-Journal) />
The artefacts that spent World War II in the care of the National Library include [[the Magna Carta]],<ref name=BBC-da_vinci /> drawings by [[Leonardo da Vinci]],<ref name=BBC-da_vinci /> paintings by [[Rembrandt]], [[Peter Paul Rubens|Rubens]] and [[Diego Velázquez|Velásquez]] from [[Dulwich College]],<ref name=Jenkins /> letters of the kings and queens of England,<ref name=BBC-da_vinci /> and manuscripts written by [[William Shakespeare]].<ref name=BBC-da_vinci />
